review: The story centers on Sylvie, a daring writer, and Killian, a heartbroken recluse, who enter a marriage of convenience after Sylvie is disowned by her parents. With $10 million on the line, she must endure a year in Killian's isolated Scottish manor. The premise is captivating, skillfully weaving together elements of romance, tension, and family drama.

Sylvie and Killian's relationship transforms from antagonism to genuine tenderness. Killian's devotion to Sylvie is both sinful and endearing, highlighting his emotional depth. Meanwhile, Sylvie evolves from reckless to understanding, learning when to stop fighting and support Killian. Their dynamic is compelling and well-developed, making the enemies-to-lovers trope shine with raw attraction and emotional intensity. The age gap adds complexity to their connection. Although their dynamic isn't as unconventional as some of the author's other couples, their passionate moments of hate-to-love are incredibly satisfying.

The author crafts a story brimming with emotion, tension, and raw passion. The writing skillfully portrays the characters' vulnerabilities and growth, making their journeys feel both authentic and engaging.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a fiercely passionate and emotionally charged romance that masterfully blends tension, family drama, and raw attraction. Sylvie and Killian's journey from enemies to lovers is both tender and intense, making for a captivating read. The author's storytelling shines, leaving readers eager for more.

review: The story centers on a faux marriage between Sylvia, a carefree spirit, and Killian, a brooding Scottish giant grappling with anger issues, aimed at restoring his image for a price. With its mix of high-stakes tension, family secrets, and a fusion of contemporary and classic Highlander romance, the narrative captivates readers. The pacing is tight, punctuated by unexpected twists such as a swingers' party and a dramatic third-act breakup that keeps the audience engaged.

Sylvia is a bold and resilient protagonist who stands her ground, making her a captivating character. In contrast, Killian is a beefy, brooding figure marked by a mix of anger and vulnerability that adds complexity to his persona. The 12-year age gap (25f / 37m) and their contrasting sizes are prominent dynamics throughout the story. The book expertly weaves explicit scenes, including BDSM, exhibitionism, and swingers' parties, that heighten the emotional and sensual stakes. The tension and jealousy during these events, particularly when Killian reacts to someone touching Sylvia, further enrich the narrative.
The author skillfully crafts moments that are both provocative and deeply intimate.

This story features key tropes such as forced proximity, a fake marriage, an age gap, and a size difference, alongside troubled protagonists and fleeting moments involving another woman. It delves into themes of loneliness, vulnerability, and the discovery of love in unexpected places.
conclusion: This book is a captivating contemporary take on the classic Highlander romance, blending broody, vulnerable characters with high-stakes tension and sizzling spice. The emotional depth, unexpected twists, and well-crafted intimate moments make it a standout read. Fans of age-gap romances, fake marriages, and steamy scenes will find this book utterly unforgettable.

review: This story effectively utilizes the enemies-to-lovers trope, which I found captivating. The narrative unfolds in alternating sections, alternating between Sylvie's and Killian's perspectives, creating a dynamic and immersive experience.

In the beginning, Sylvie appears to be a carefree individual who leans on her renowned artist parents for financial support, seemingly indifferent to the repercussions. Yet, as the narrative unfolds, readers gain insight into both her parents and her true motivations. Meanwhile, Killian has retreated into isolation following his parents' death a decade ago. His sister's worry prompts her to orchestrate a fake marriage, marking a pivotal moment in his life.
Set in Scotland and New York, the story paints Scotland as a frequent rainy backdrop.

The story delves into themes of family dynamics, personal growth, and the intricacies of relationships. It effectively illustrates the impact of choices and how unforeseen events can dramatically change the trajectory of one's life.
conclusion: This novel is a well-crafted blend of romance, humor, and emotional depth. The alternating POVs, engaging plot, and strong character development make it a compelling read. The audiobook narration, particularly the Scottish accent, adds an extra layer of enjoyment.

I love it when characters need time to heal and realize that sometimes, love alone isn't enough to achieve your HEA. Sara is a master at creating characters that you instantly understand, relate to, and root for, even when you think you won't. How could I possibly relate to a grumpy Scotsman? Turns out I do!

- **Narration Performance:**  
  The acting was phenomenal! Both Kelli and Will are excellent at accent work. I had to keep reminding myself that this was a romance with an HEA, but thanks to the incredible acting and Sara's storytelling, I was still sobbing for these two. This audio is dual narration. I loved Kelli's rich and sultry voice. Her male Scottish voice was spot-on and oh-so-perfect! I love it when female narrators, with their talents alone, make you swoon for the MMC! She nailed all the accents, making it easy to tell each character apart while empathizing with their plight. This is the first audio of hers I've done, but I am hooked!! Will has a wonderfully deep and robust vocal range. His Scottish grump is perfect and so swoony! I don't think I've heard a book he's narrated that I haven't loved. I need more of this man in my ears. He is so talented!

- **Emotional Engagement:**  
  The story was fan-f*cking-tastic! I was so invested in Killian and Sylvie's journey that I found myself sobbing for them, even though I knew they would get their HEA. Sara's storytelling, combined with the incredible narration, made the emotional depth of the story truly resonate with me.

**Conclusion:**  
This novel is a masterclass in character development and emotional storytelling, brought to life by phenomenal narration. Sara's ability to create relatable, broken characters and the exceptional voice acting by Kelli and Will made this an unforgettable experience. I was completely immersed in the story, laughing, crying, and rooting for Killian and Sylvie every step of the way.

**Rating Scores:**  
(No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.)

Both Killian and Sylvie grapple with personal traumas and unresolved issues that have hindered their ability to embrace love. The portrayal of mental illness and agoraphobia is handled sensitively, adding depth to their characters. Their journey of mutual support through these struggles is both heartwarming and emotionally impactful.
The writing is captivating and skillfully crafted, effectively illustrating the intricacies of the characters and their relationships.

This book is an emotional rollercoaster, evoking laughter and tears through its beautifully crafted depiction of love and heartbreak. The characters' journey of growth and healing together is profoundly moving.

review: This novel presents a marriage of convenience, featuring grumpy characters, a brooding Scottish billionaire, and a compelling hate-to-love dynamic intensified by forced proximity. While the eight-month separation in the third act is crucial for Killian's character growth, the journey to love itself feels somewhat rushed and underdeveloped.

In this engaging story, we meet Killian, a brooding Scottish billionaire, and Sylvie, a spirited and stubborn New Yorker. Their contrasting personalities create a well-balanced dynamic that drives their compelling dislike-to-love journey. Memorable moments, such as Killian's late-night visit to Sylvie and his bold move to oust her parents from his home, highlight their intriguing relationship.

The dual POV structure was skillfully executed, allowing each character to shine with multiple consecutive chapters. This approach enhanced the emotional depth of the story, evoking tears from both the characters and the reader alike.
The story poignantly examines the emotional growth and healing of its two main characters, Killian and Sylvie, as they journey through their relationship.
conclusion: This novel delivers a compelling hate-to-love romance with well-balanced characters, emotional depth, and a touch of spice. While the falling-in-love process felt slightly rushed, the overall story, character growth, and narration made it an enjoyable read.

review: The story's premise‚Äîa modern marriage of convenience intertwined with deceit‚Äîoffers a refreshing twist on a classic trope. This dynamic elevates the stakes, ensuring my investment as the characters navigate their evolving relationship and the challenges it presents.

Killian Barclay, the brooding hero, is a man weighed down by heartbreak and seeking solace in indulgence‚Äîan experience many can relate to. In contrast, Sylvie Devereaux embodies fierce independence, shaped by a past of neglect. Her transformation from guarded detachment to vulnerability parallels Killian's reluctant embrace of hope and connection. Their characters are beautifully developed through a blend of fiery banter and tender moments, highlighting their emotional growth throughout the story.

The Scottish backdrop of Barclay Manor evokes a poignant charm, symbolizing the emotional barriers the protagonists must confront. This setting not only enriches the mood but also offers a deeply immersive experience.

In *Keep Me*, the author weaves a captivating narrative that intertwines passion, vulnerability, and redemption. The story thoughtfully explores themes of self-worth, healing, and the transformative power of love. This poignant examination makes the characters' emotional journeys deeply impactful and relatable.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a seductive and deeply emotional tale that lingers long after the final page. The author's masterful storytelling, combined with the evocative setting, compelling character development, and exceptional narration, makes this novel a standout in the contemporary romance genre.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Narrative and Themes:**  
  Sara Cate crafts a captivating narrative in *Keep Me*, intertwining passion, vulnerability, and redemption. The story beautifully delves into themes of self-worth, healing, and the transformative power of love. The exploration of these themes is both poignant and relatable, making the emotional journey of the characters deeply impactful.  

- **Character Development:**  
  Killian Barclay, the brooding hero, is a man burdened by heartbreak, a feeling many can relate to, who seeks solace in indulgence. Sylvie Devereaux, a woman hardened by neglect, resonates with her fierce independence. Sylvie's journey from guarded detachment to vulnerability is as compelling as Killian's reluctant surrender to hope and connection. The depth of their characters is revealed through fiery banter and tender moments, showcasing their emotional growth.  

- **Setting and Atmosphere:**  
  The Scottish setting adds an evocative charm, with Barclay Manor serving as both a backdrop and a metaphor for the emotional walls the protagonists must navigate. The setting enhances the story's mood and provides a rich, immersive experience.  

- **Plot and Premise:**  
  The story's premise‚Äîa modern marriage of convenience laced with deceit‚Äîprovides a fresh spin on a classic trope. This keeps the stakes high and the reader invested, as the characters navigate their evolving relationship and the challenges it brings.  

- **Narration and Performance (Audiobook):**  
  Kelli Tager and Will Watt breathe life into this captivating story through their narration. Tager perfectly captures Sylvie's sharp wit and emotional growth, while Watt's portrayal of Killian's smouldering intensity and vulnerability is mesmerizing. Their dynamic performance elevates the story, drawing listeners into the characters' evolving relationship and amplifying the emotional resonance of every scene.  

- **Comparison to Other Works:**  
  In comparison to other contemporary romance novels, *Keep Me* stands out due to Cate's masterful storytelling and the exceptional narration by Tager and Watt. The depth of its characters and the exploration of themes make it a memorable and standout read.  

**Conclusion:**  
*Keep Me* is a seductive and deeply emotional tale that lingers long after the final page. Sara Cate's masterful storytelling, combined with the evocative setting, compelling character development, and exceptional narration, makes this novel a standout in the contemporary romance genre.

review: The ending is beautifully crafted, tying up the characters' arcs while leaving readers craving more. The story centers on a hate-to-love romance between Killian Barclay, a reclusive Scottish hero with a troubled past, and Sylvie Devereaux, a fiery and independent New Yorker. The premise features a marriage of convenience, as Sylvie agrees to marry Killian for one year to help rehabilitate his playboy reputation in exchange for ten million dollars. With its emotional depth, themes of healing, and steamy moments, this tale is a compelling read.

Sylvie is a smart, passionate, and resilient character who navigates her unsupportive parents while rediscovering her love for writing. In contrast, Killian is a complex figure, burdened by the loss of his parents and grappling with emotional isolation. Both characters experience significant growth as they confront their personal struggles and forge a genuine connection. Their relationship unfolds as a classic hate-to-love story, marked by witty banter, sharp insults, and undeniable chemistry. The transition from animosity to love is both entertaining and heartwarming, with their eventual surrender to attraction serving as a standout moment in the narrative.
The book features alternating perspectives from Killian and Sylvie, enriching the narrative. The writing is emotional, spicy, and engaging, reflecting the author's signature style.

The story is profoundly emotional, with poignant moments that resonate deeply, especially in Killian‚Äôs backstory and Sylvie‚Äôs family struggles. The growth and healing they undergo make their journey both satisfying and impactful.
conclusion: Keep Me is a steamy, emotional, and healing romance that delivers on its promise of a compelling hate-to-love story. With well-developed characters, witty banter, and a satisfying emotional arc, it‚Äôs a book that leaves readers wanting more.

review: This story may seem like a typical arranged marriage romance at first glance, but it delves deeply into themes of family, grief, and personal growth. The narrative skillfully intertwines love, secrets, and emotional healing, leading to a satisfying happily-ever-after. With masterful execution of the enemies-to-lovers, opposites-attract, and billionaire romance tropes, the plot remains engaging and difficult to set aside. The author‚Äôs storytelling ability is evident in the constant tension and emotional depth, keeping readers invested from beginning to end.

The protagonists, Sylvie and Killian, are intricately developed and compelling. Sylvie, a fiery American woman, endures numerous hardships, making her an easy character to root for. In contrast, Killian is a grumpy recluse burdened by emotional scars and a family that struggles to comprehend his grief. As the story unfolds, both characters undergo significant growth, evolving from enemies to friends and ultimately to lovers as they uncover each other‚Äôs secrets and vulnerabilities.
Scotland's stunning landscapes provide an ideal backdrop for this romance, while the ancestral manor house enhances the charm and sets the perfect stage for the story.

Though it lacks the spiciness of some of the author's other works, this story still offers a compelling mix of passion and steam. The slow-burn romance between Sylvie and Killian is artfully crafted, with their emotional walls coming down as they reveal their true selves to one another.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a masterfully crafted romance that combines a captivating setting, well-developed characters, and a deeply emotional plot. The audiobook narration elevates the experience, making it a standout listen. With its blend of passion, growth, and heartfelt storytelling, this novel is a must-read (or listen) for fans of slow-burn, enemies-to-lovers romances.

review: The story follows Sylvie and Killian, whose tumultuous relationship begins with a hostile encounter when Sylvie intrudes on Killian's Scottish manor. Initially fueled by animosity, their connection evolves into a marriage of convenience, arranged by Killian's family to restore his tarnished reputation. As the narrative unfolds, their hatred gradually transforms into genuine affection and true love. The emotionally charged plot centers on their journey from animosity to romance, enhanced by a fiery chemistry that keeps readers engaged.

Sylvie presents as a strong, sassy woman, yet beneath her tough exterior lies a deep vulnerability and a longing for the acceptance and love she never received from her parents. Killian, initially portrayed as a hardened and intimidating figure, is ultimately revealed to be a sad, lonely man wrestling with his own past traumas. The heart of the story lies in their emotional growth and the way they come to understand and love each other's true selves. The hate-to-love trope is skillfully executed, with their fiery chemistry and passionate encounters adding depth to their relationship. While this story may not be as spicy as some of the author's other works, it prioritizes emotional intensity and the genuine connection that blossoms between Sylvie and Killian.

This story is rich with strong emotions, delivering a passionate and heartfelt experience. The compelling transformation of the characters' relationship from hate to love creates a lasting impression.
conclusion: This is a passionate and emotionally charged hate-to-love story that focuses on the deep connection and growth between Sylvie and Killian. While it may not be as spicy as some of the author's other works, it excels in delivering a heartfelt and engaging romance that keeps readers invested in the characters' journey.

review: The story centers on self-discovery and personal growth. However, the marketing's emphasis on partner swapping felt misleading; it primarily featured Killian reminiscing about past parties, with the main characters only engaging in a brief spin-the-bottle scene that culminated in a single kiss. While the side characters played a more active role in this aspect, it ultimately felt like a secondary subplot.

I thoroughly enjoyed Sylvie and Killian's love story. Initially, Sylvie seemed chaotic, with the potential for an unlikable personality, but she evolved and became more self-assured. Killian, despite being a billionaire, defied the typical obnoxious stereotype; he was simply a guy tending to his bees, using his wealth thoughtfully and never in a distasteful manner. The hate-to-love trope was beautifully executed, capturing the profound experience of being truly seen and emotionally fulfilled by someone. Their romance felt genuine and heartfelt.

This book had a profound emotional impact on me. I found myself sobbing while making lunch, particularly during the final chapters. It truly resonated with me, and I still haven't fully composed myself even after finishing it.
conclusion: This book was an emotional rollercoaster that left me deeply moved. The characters were well-developed, the romance was heartfelt, and the themes of self-discovery and personal growth resonated strongly. Despite some mislabeling in the marketing, the story was beautifully executed and left a lasting impression.

While I couldn't relate to her, her journey toward self-actualization by the end of the story was compelling, despite her retaining some flaws. Killian, on the other hand, battles deep-seated guilt and self-harm due to his failure to seek proper mental outlets. I could partially relate to his struggles, and his character undergoes a significant transformation, acknowledging that he still has room to grow.

Initially, I struggled to connect with the characters, but by the end of the story, I found myself loving both Sylvie and Killian. The book moved me to tears, making it one of the most emotionally impactful love stories I‚Äôve read from this author. Although I didn‚Äôt see much of myself in either character and my reasoning for their actions didn‚Äôt align with theirs, the narrative‚Äôs ability to subvert my expectations and evoke such deep care for them speaks volumes about its strength.
conclusion: While I initially disliked Sylvie and Killian due to their flaws and lack of relatability, their realistic portrayal and growth throughout the story won me over. The emotional depth and transformation of the characters made this a standout read, bringing me to tears and solidifying it as one of the author‚Äôs best works.

review: The novel centers on a marriage of convenience between Sylvie, a spirited American, and Killian, a grumpy Scotsman. Initially set for one year, their arrangement proves difficult for both. The story skillfully traces their transformation from animosity to love, making for an engaging read.

Sylvie and Killian each grapple with personal challenges, and witnessing their growth throughout the story is profoundly emotional. Their evolving relationship is monumental and treated with great care. The hate-to-love trope is one of the best I've encountered, with their sharp banter and undeniable chemistry making their gradual transition into something deeper incredibly compelling. The emotional depth and vulnerability in their connection are especially moving.

The dialogue is sharp and passionate, brimming with memorable lines that underscore the intensity of the characters' connection. Quotes such as ‚ÄúI need to be inside you, Sylvie. I need to make you my wife‚Äù and ‚ÄúJust because I can do it without you doesn‚Äôt mean I want to‚Äù capture the raw emotion and intimacy between them.
The story elicited powerful emotions, with moments that brought me to tears. The characters' transformation and their evolving relationship felt genuine and profoundly impactful.
conclusion: This novel was a delightful surprise, offering a fresh take on the marriage-of-convenience trope. The characters‚Äô growth, their fiery chemistry, and the emotional depth of their journey made this a standout read. The audiobook narration further elevated the experience, making it a truly immersive and memorable story.

review: *Keep Me*, the first installment in the Sinful Manner Series, showcases some of my favorite tropes: enemies-to-lovers, fake marriage, and an age gap. The inclusion of a Scottish brute as the male main character only heightened my enjoyment and made me swoon.

I was deeply captivated by Killian and Sylvie. Their relationship begins as a contractual arrangement: Sylvie seeks financial security, while Killian hopes to preserve his peaceful, solitary life. review: This book, the first in the Sinful Manor series, centers on Killian and Sylvie, narrated from both of their perspectives. The story kicks off with Sylvie breaking into Killian's house to snap a picture of a typewriter for her boyfriend, leading to a humorous encounter. As events unfold, Sylvie ends her relationship and faces challenges with her parents. She then agrees to a fake engagement with Killian, and as they live together, she uncovers deeper layers to his character. The narrative explores whether their pretend relationship will evolve into genuine feelings, if Killian can confront his past, and if Sylvie can resolve her family issues.

Killian and Sylvie are richly developed characters, each with distinct personalities that shine through their engaging banter, which adds both humor and depth to the narrative. Sylvie's growth is particularly notable as she confronts her personal challenges and her evolving relationship with Killian. Meanwhile, Killian's mysterious past adds complexity, making him an intriguing and layered character.
The dual point of view enables readers to connect with both protagonists and gain insight into their perspectives.
The humor and banter among the characters make the story both engaging and enjoyable. The pacing is well-crafted, featuring enough twists and emotional moments to keep me invested throughout.
conclusion: I thoroughly enjoyed *Keep Me* for its engaging plot, well-developed characters, and witty banter. The story kept me invested from start to finish, and I‚Äôm excited to see where the narrative goes next.

conclusion: Despite some initial reservations about the characters, *Keep Me* by the author ultimately won me over with its engaging plot, character growth, and emotional depth. The author delivers another compelling story that keeps readers hooked until the end.

Sylvie, on the other hand, is relatable and hilarious, especially her impulsive decision to move to Scotland to marry a man who initially despised her. The forced proximity and their slow-building bond were beautifully crafted, making their journey of opening up and falling in love truly heartwarming. I absolutely adored their relationship.
conclusion: This book was a delightful surprise, blending humor, romance, and a slow-burn relationship that I couldn‚Äôt get enough of. review: The story features several time jumps, leaving me longing for more in-depth moments between Killian and Sylvie. The ending felt abrupt and lacking in closure, which was disappointing; while epilogues aren't essential, a more resolved conclusion would have been welcome. That said, the marriage of convenience trope, along with the Beauty and the Beast vibes, made for an enjoyable read. Focused on Killian, a reclusive Scottish billionaire, and Sylvie, who finds herself caught breaking into his mansion, their relationship transitions from enemies to lovers, infused with plenty of tension and chemistry.

Killian and Sylvie have strong personalities that initially clash, reminiscent of cats and dogs. Their sudden realization of chemistry may feel abrupt, but it aligns well with their characters. Both are grumpy, enhancing their dynamic, while their forced proximity fosters growth and connection.

The romance primarily unfolds in Killian's mansion, echoing the Beauty and the Beast theme. However, the story would have been enhanced by exploring additional settings. The briefly mentioned parties hosted by Killian felt underdeveloped, missing an opportunity for richer storytelling.
conclusion: Overall, this was a fun read with enjoyable tropes and strong character dynamics. However, the story could have benefited from more detailed development of certain plot points and a more satisfying conclusion. While it wasn‚Äôt my favorite from this author, I think many readers will still find it entertaining.

review: In this captivating tale, Sylvie finds herself trespassing in a Scottish manor, where she has a heated encounter with Killian Barclay. Fresh from a breakup with her unfaithful boyfriend, Sylvie is approached by Killian's sister with a tempting offer: marry Killian for a year in exchange for $10 million, with the twist being their mutual disdain and her plan to evict him from his home afterward. The tension and banter between Sylvie and Killian are delightfully intense, leaving me utterly captivated. Claire, the villain, is so infuriating that she has earned a spot on my list of least favorite characters. When the tension finally breaks and Sylvie and Killian surrender to their desires, it‚Äôs nothing short of explosive. The story masterfully weaves together themes of hate, love, and personal growth.

Although I found myself wanting to shake both main characters for their outrageous attitudes, unreasonable expectations, and poor communication, their growth was truly remarkable. This beautiful story of love, loss, struggle, and achievement ultimately warmed my heart.
A captivating hate-to-love story set in the Scottish Highlands, featuring a male narrator whose accent is simply perfect.

This book delivered an unparalleled level of angst. The third-act breakup shattered me; despite anticipating it, the emotional impact was profound. The author masterfully weaves together elements of angst, spice, and taboo, creating a truly unforgettable experience.
conclusion: This novel was an emotional rollercoaster filled with angst, spice, and unforgettable tension. Despite the characters' flaws and the inevitable third-act breakup, their growth and the heartwarming resolution made it a truly satisfying read. The author masterfully crafted a story of love, loss, and triumph set against the stunning backdrop of the Scottish Highlands.

review: The story centers on a marriage of convenience between tough New Yorker Sylvie Devereaux and Scottish playboy Killian Barclay. Initially caught sneaking into Barclay Manor, Sylvie is presented with a deal by Killian's sister: marry Killian to enhance his reputation, stay for a year, and receive $10 million. However, the true intention is for Sylvie to win Barclay Manor in the divorce and hand it over to Killian's manipulative family. The plot is emotionally charged, filled with tension and passion as the characters' relationship evolves.

Sylvie and Killian are strong-willed characters whose frequent clashes create a dynamic rich in tension and chemistry. What begins as a contentious arrangement gradually evolves into a passionate connection. Their emotional journey is marked by frustration, anticipation, and heartbreak, especially during the poignant third-act breakup.

The author is renowned for her spicy, kink-focused novels, but *Keep Me* is notably more subdued. While it includes elements of BDSM, the primary emphasis is on the emotional and romantic growth of the characters. The story is engaging and elicits a variety of emotions, making it an enjoyable read.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is an emotionally charged and entertaining marriage-of-convenience romance set in Scotland. While it is less intense in terms of kink compared to the author's other works, it delivers a compelling story with strong character dynamics and a satisfying emotional arc. The audiobook narration, especially Will Watt's Scottish burr, adds an extra layer of enjoyment to the experience.

review: I love a couple that uses bickering as foreplay, and *Keep Me* delivers just that. Sylvie, shaped by a neglectful past and a string of bad partners, is determined to stand on her own. When offered a $10 million boon, she agrees to deceive Killian, the man who recently rejected her. Beneath his gruff exterior, Killian harbors deep wounds, and Sylvie sees through his defenses. Their constant sparring reignites his sense of vitality, complicating his feelings of hatred toward her. The first half of the book captivated me with the characters' emotional armor; both are defensive yet yearning for love, unsure how to embrace it. By the halfway mark, Killian enters his "My Wife" phase, while Sylvie becomes focused on helping him heal from his past traumas, drawn to his physicality in the process.
If you appreciate Grumpy X Grumpy dynamics, playful nicknames, and light kink, this book is an excellent choice.

The first half of the book masterfully builds tension and emotional depth, but once the characters begin to open up, I devoured the rest in one sitting. Part 5 had my heart in a vice grip, delivering an intense emotional payoff that highlighted the characters' journey.
conclusion: *Keep Me* by the author is a captivating romance that combines emotional depth, witty banter, and steamy tension. The characters‚Äô journey from defensive sparring to vulnerability and healing is both engaging and heartwarming. The pacing keeps you hooked, especially in the second half, and the emotional payoff is deeply satisfying.

  The second half of the book was harder to get through. While I understand that the MMC (male main character) has a lot to work through, the way it unfolded felt choppy and disjointed compared to the rest of the book.  

- **Character Development and Roles:**  
  The FMC (female main character) is a writer, but this aspect of her character feels underutilized. Her finished book comes out of nowhere, which felt abrupt and underdeveloped.  

- **Dialogue and Character Dynamics:**  
  The MMC literally calls the FMC a ‚Äúcow‚Äù and ‚Äúwench.‚Äù I get that they‚Äôre supposed to dislike each other, but the choice of words felt unnecessarily harsh and off-putting.  

**Conclusion:**  
While the book starts strong with an engaging and easy-to-read narrative reminiscent of *Beauty and the Beast*, the second half struggles with pacing and cohesion. The underdeveloped aspects of the FMC‚Äôs role as a writer and the jarring dialogue between the main characters detract from the overall experience.  

**Rating Scores:**  
3.5/5

It follows 25-year-old Sylvie Devereaux, who, after being cut off financially and emotionally by her parents, finds herself in a difficult situation when she discovers her boyfriend with her best friend. Enter Killian, a 37- or 38-year-old recluse, who agrees to a marriage of convenience with Sylvie to dispel rumors that he runs a sex club from his home. The story opens with trigger warnings, hinting at a darker, spicier narrative, but it ultimately feels less intense than expected. While the first half is somewhat awkward and clumsy, the second half picks up momentum as the characters' relationship evolves.

In this story, Sylvie grapples with her identity amid her parents' neglect, while Killian confronts the trauma of his parents' death, battling panic attacks and anger. Initially, both characters come across as rude and entitled, but they become increasingly relatable as the narrative unfolds, particularly in the second half. Their compelling growth is highlighted as they support each other in navigating their struggles and discovering hope.
The dual POV is skillfully executed, with both narrators effectively capturing their characters' emotions and accents.
The narrative delves into themes of emotional trauma, self-discovery, and healing, showcasing significant growth in both characters.

The romance takes center stage, featuring a blend of sweet, heartbreaking, funny, spicy, and tender moments. While the spicy scenes are present, they constitute only a small part of the narrative, with the main focus on emotional connection and healing.
conclusion: Keep Me is a decent read with a mix of romance, self-reflection, and healing. While it didn‚Äôt deliver the darker, spicier tone suggested by the trigger warnings, it offered a compelling exploration of emotional trauma and personal growth. Overall, it‚Äôs a satisfying story with a focus on love and self-discovery.

review: The story centers on Sylvie Devereaux, the overlooked daughter of two prominent figures in the art world, who finds herself cut off from her allowance for reasons that resonate with me. Their marriage is purely transactional: Sylvie stands to gain $10 million after a year, while Killian seeks a respectable wife to quell his family's concerns about his wild lifestyle. The beginning of their year together is as tumultuous as their first encounter, leaving me curious about how they will navigate the challenges ahead.

The first half of the book was challenging for me due to the unlikable main characters. I questioned whether the author could redeem them enough for me to enjoy the story. However, by the 70% mark, I found myself rooting for them. Despite its themes of swinging and kinks, the book felt surprisingly tame. conclusion: While this book didn‚Äôt quite meet my expectations compared to the author‚Äôs earlier works, it‚Äôs still a worthwhile read. They propose that Sylvie move in, marry Killian, enhance his reputation, and, after a year of pretense, walk away with ten million dollars. As Sylvie and Killian grow closer, she faces a difficult choice: is his love worth the risk of breaking his heart?

The author skillfully balances a steamy narrative with profound themes, particularly in tackling challenging issues. From the outset, Killian and Sylvie grapple with their emotions and personal struggles, and the entire story focuses on their growth and transformation, which is captivating to witness. conclusion: This novel is a masterful blend of steamy romance and emotional depth, with well-developed characters and a compelling enemies-to-lovers dynamic. The growth of Killian and Sylvie, along with the intense emotional journey, made this story unforgettable.

review: The story centers on Sylvia Devereaux, who finds herself at rock bottom‚Äîunemployed, broke, and betrayed by her boyfriend and best friend. She is approached by the sister of a wealthy Scottish family with a proposition: marry her brother, Killian, for one year in exchange for $10 million. This marriage is a strategic move to reclaim the family estate, which will revert to them if Killian remains married for a year. The premise is captivating, as Sylvie and Killian navigate their evolving feelings against the enchanting backdrop of a picturesque Irish estate.

Sylvie and Killian's relationship transitions from a contractual arrangement to a deeper connection, as both characters grapple with their growing feelings. However, Killian's initial use of derogatory names like "cow," "c*nt," and "b*tch" made for uncomfortable reading. While this dynamic may resonate with fans of bully romance, it posed a challenge for me.

The story is a delight to read, featuring witty banter and a playful tone. The spice level is impressively high and expertly crafted‚Äîtruly SPICIN‚Äô. This book reveals a fresh side of the author‚Äôs writing, which I thoroughly enjoyed.
After overcoming the initial discomfort, I quickly became engrossed in the story. The book was incredibly fun and engaging, making for an overall enjoyable read.
conclusion: Keep Me by the author is a captivating and spicy romance with a unique premise and witty banter. While the beginning was uncomfortable due to the MMC‚Äôs harsh language, the story quickly became engaging and enjoyable. It showcases a different side of the author‚Äôs writing, making it a fun and memorable read.

review: I was instantly captivated by the concept of a fake marriage between Killian Barclay, a brooding Scotsman, and Sylvie Devereaux, an independent New Yorker. The story unfolds as Sylvie agrees to marry Killian, a complete stranger, under a one-year legal contract. I was intrigued by the challenge she faces: can she endure her hot-headed, party-loving husband and emerge a multimillionaire?

Throughout the novel, I became enamored with Killian and Sylvie. Both characters possess profound layers of love and compassion. Their journeys of self-discovery and the effort they invest in uncovering the layers guarding their hearts make their growth both compelling and relatable.
This book is brimming with snark, steamy banter, and spice, making it both engaging and entertaining. The balance of humor, romance, and emotional depth is expertly crafted.
The novel delves into themes of self-discovery, trust, and found family. Its emotional depth, coupled with the characters' journeys, brings a genuine authenticity and warmth to the narrative.
I wholeheartedly recommend *Keep Me* and eagerly anticipate more works from this talented author. With a release date of December 3rd, I encourage readers to preorder their copies.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a captivating novel that combines a unique premise, well-developed characters, and a perfect blend of humor, romance, and emotional depth. It‚Äôs a story that will leave you rooting for the characters and eager to explore more of the author‚Äôs work.

review: The story follows Sylvie, a resilient woman shaped by a challenging past, who enters into a marriage of convenience with Killian, a Scottish man known for his wild reputation. In return for marrying him and staying faithful for a year, she is promised $10 million and a chance at a new life. While both characters have much to gain from the arrangement, their conflicting personalities and concealed vulnerabilities lead to tension and surprising emotional depth.

Sylvie is a strong, guarded woman who has erected high walls around herself due to her troubled past. In contrast, Killian is a Scottish brute known for his wild behavior. Their dynamic as two alphas who challenge and ultimately transform one another is captivating. The evolution of their relationship from enemies to lovers is intense and deeply satisfying.

This book boasts a captivating tone infused with a playful kinkiness that enhances its allure. The narrative skillfully balances steamy moments with emotional depth, keeping readers thoroughly engaged. The author masterfully crafts both the female and male protagonists, making them loveable yet frustrating, which adds to the story's charm.

The novel delves into themes of trust, vulnerability, and the transformative power of love. It challenges the notion of whether sacrificing one's dreams for financial security is worthwhile or if embracing risks for love leads to true fulfillment.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a captivating enemies-to-lovers romance with a marriage of convenience twist. The dynamic between Sylvie and Killian is electric, blending tension, passion, and emotional growth. The story is both steamy and heartfelt, making it a satisfying read for fans of the genre.

review: The story opens with Sylvie Devereaux breaking into her ancestral manor to photograph a typewriter, only to be unexpectedly offered $10 million to marry the grumpy Scottish man, Killian, whom she barely knows. This intriguing premise sets the stage for a unique and engaging narrative.

Sylvie and Killian's stubbornness and similarities create hilarious and compelling interactions. Initially, I found Killian off-putting due to his name-calling, but as he softened toward Sylvie, I grew to appreciate his character. Their evolving dynamic beautifully showcases vulnerability and growth. The slow-burn romance, filled with angst, was surprisingly enjoyable, and the well-written spicy scenes added depth to their relationship. Killian's transformation from a broody, vulgar man to someone who finds solace in Sylvie's support is truly heartwarming.

The writing was engaging, striking a fine balance between humor, tension, and emotional depth. Killian's dialogue, particularly lines like, ‚ÄúLet me see it again, darling. You come so pretty,‚Äù infused the narrative with a unique charm.

The book skillfully weaves together several tropes, including Age Gap (25/38), Forced Proximity, Marriage of Convenience, Enemies to Lovers, and Grumpy/Grumpy. These elements are well-executed, adding depth to the story and maintaining my engagement throughout.

Killian's longing for a "soft place to land" and unconditional acceptance‚Äîembracing both his strengths and flaws‚Äîdeeply resonated with me. It prompted me to reflect on my own needs and desires, creating a personal connection to the story.
conclusion: This book was a delightful mix of angst, humor, and romance. The slow-burn relationship between Sylvie and Killian was both entertaining and emotionally satisfying. The tropes were well-executed, and the spicy scenes were a highlight. I‚Äôm eagerly looking forward to the next book in the series!

Their unexpected meeting sparks an addictive marriage of convenience, captivating readers as they question whether the two can coexist. The narrative explores their intense animosity, tender moments, and emotional challenges, ultimately leading to a heartfelt journey of healing.

Killian, a reclusive and brooding Scotsman haunted by heartbreak, initially isolates himself from others. As both characters confront their inner demons, their emotional journey culminates in a poignant breakup in the third act. However, their growth and healing keep me deeply invested in their story.

The author skillfully balances fiery disdain with tender moments, crafting a compelling dynamic between the characters. Although this writing style differs from the author's usual approach, it is beautifully executed and effectively conveys the story's emotional depth.

conclusion: This enemies-to-lovers story is a beautifully crafted tale of tension, emotional depth, and healing. While different from her usual style, the novel is a standout piece that leaves readers eagerly anticipating more.

review: I anticipated a story heavy on spice rather than plot, but I was pleasantly surprised to find a compelling narrative alongside the heat. The tale centers on a grumpy Scottish billionaire known for his playboy ways and an American tourist whom his family persuades to marry him. He believes this union will enhance his reputation and secure his family castle, but the marriage contract holds deeper secrets. Their relationship evolves from strangers to adversaries, filled with conflict and banter, before blossoming into something more profound as they share their pasts and struggles. The tension escalates when he uncovers the true reason behind her agreement to marry him.

The male main character (MMC) is grumpy, morally gray, and not the typical golden retriever type, which may not resonate with all readers. However, his redemption arc is satisfying, leading to a sweeter conclusion than I expected. The female main character (FMC) is well-developed, and the dual POV enriches their evolving relationship.

The book skillfully weaves together popular tropes such as forced proximity, grumpy/grumpy dynamics, enemies to lovers, marriage of convenience, and a reformed playboy. Additionally, its representation of mental health adds significant emotional depth to the narrative.
conclusion: This book exceeded my expectations with its blend of spice, plot, and character development. While the MMC starts off as mean and morally gray, his redemption arc and the evolving relationship between the two main characters make the story emotionally satisfying. If you enjoy complex characters and a mix of tension and romance, this is a great read.

review: The premise of the MFC being chosen for the marriage felt contrived and lacked adequate explanation, making it difficult to fully engage with the setup.

This novel effectively uses romance as a means of healing, telling the story of two individuals with deep parental trauma who are thrust into an arranged marriage, forcing them to confront their personal demons. This theme is beautifully executed and resonates powerfully. However, I found it challenging to connect with the main characters. The female protagonist (MFC) often comes across as spoiled and entitled, particularly in her expectation that her parents should support her despite her poor financial choices. Meanwhile, the male protagonist (MMC) is largely unlikable; his frequent derogatory name-calling, including referring to the MFC as a "cow," is unacceptable and detracts from the reading experience.

The spice in the book was well-crafted, but considering the trigger warnings, I anticipated a darker, more taboo tone. Instead, the spice came across as somewhat generic, which was acceptable but ultimately fell short of my expectations for a dark romance.
conclusion: While the novel has its flaws, particularly in character likability and plot convenience, it excels in its portrayal of romance as a means of healing. The themes of friendship, love, and overcoming personal demons make it a worthwhile read, though it may not fully satisfy those seeking a darker, more taboo tone.

  The premise of the MFC being chosen for the marriage felt contrived and lacked sufficient explanation, which made it hard to fully buy into the setup.

Their constant bickering, filled with insults like "asshole," "brute," "cow," and "wrench," is balanced by tender moments, such as when Killian affectionately calls Sylvie "mo ghraidh" (darling and wife). As their hatred evolves into passion, their journey becomes incredibly compelling. Both characters experience significant growth, helping each other in unique ways and providing exactly what the other needs. Their profound love is beautifully portrayed, leaving me in awe of their connection.

This book took me on an emotional rollercoaster‚Äîanger, joy, pride, heartbreak, and even laughter. I found myself kicking my feet in excitement and shedding tears. It truly evoked a full spectrum of feelings.
conclusion: This novel is an emotional rollercoaster with a deeply satisfying love story. Sylvie and Killian‚Äôs journey from hatred to passion is beautifully written, and their growth as individuals and as a couple is inspiring. I‚Äôm grateful to have experienced their story and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a heartfelt and engaging read.

review: The ending left me feeling confused and unsatisfied. The abrupt emotional shift in the mother‚Äôs character, coupled with the unresolved issues surrounding the parents' mistreatment, made the conclusion feel incomplete.

The MFC's response to betrayal was disappointing. Her reaction to being betrayed by her boyfriend and best friend lacked the expected pettiness and assertiveness. I had hoped for a more dramatic and satisfying retaliation, like sending a risqu√© photo of herself with her new spouse, lounging on a pile of money next to a typewriter.
The novel skillfully weaves together themes of enemies to lovers, forced proximity, BDSM, and found family, which are central to its narrative and enhance its overall tone and appeal.
conclusion: While the novel successfully incorporates engaging themes like enemies-to-lovers and found family, the character development of the MFC and the portrayal of parental relationships fell short of expectations. The ending, in particular, felt inconsistent and left several unresolved issues, detracting from the overall satisfaction of the story.

  The MFC's response to betrayal felt underwhelming. Specifically, her reaction to the betrayal by her boyfriend and best friend lacked the level of pettiness or assertiveness I expected. I envisioned a more dramatic or satisfying retaliation, such as sending a risqu√© photo of her and her new spouse lying on a pile of money next to a typewriter.  

- **Parental Relationships:**  
  The portrayal of the parents, particularly the mother, was frustrating. Their mistreatment of the daughter was consistent throughout the story, but the sudden shift in the mother's emotions at the end felt inconsistent and poorly explained. It was unclear why she suddenly seemed hurt or remorseful about their past behavior when they had shown little care for their daughter previously.  

- **Ending:**  
  The ending left me confused and unsatisfied. The sudden emotional shift in the mother's character and the lack of resolution regarding the parents' mistreatment made the conclusion feel abrupt and unresolved.  

**Conclusion:**  
While the novel successfully incorporates engaging themes like enemies-to-lovers and found family, the character development of the MFC and the portrayal of parental relationships fell short of expectations. The ending, in particular, felt inconsistent and left several unresolved issues, detracting from the overall satisfaction of the story.

review: Sylvie's life takes a dramatic turn when her parents cut her off financially and stop responding to her calls. Struggling with writer's block, she finds herself in Scotland with her boyfriend, only to accidentally trespass into a mansion owned by Killian, who breaks her phone in the process. Her situation worsens when she uncovers her boyfriend's affair with her best friend. The plot takes an intriguing twist when Killian's sister offers Sylvie $10 million to marry him, setting the stage for a unique romance.

This book explores the emotional struggles of Sylvie and Killian with depth and nuance. Sylvie's journey from rock bottom to discovering her strength and purpose is compelling, while Killian's reclusiveness and trauma are examined in detail. Their mutual healing process enriches their relationship. Although their initial interactions can be jarring‚Äîespecially Killian's harsh tone toward Sylvie‚Äîtheir bond evolves into a meaningful connection rooted in understanding and support as the story unfolds.

This BDSM romance, set against the captivating backdrop of Scotland, showcases the author's signature style. The writing is engaging, and the story flows seamlessly once the initial tension between the characters is resolved.
The book's exploration of trauma and healing is a standout feature. The characters' emotional depth and their journeys toward coping with their pasts resonated deeply with me.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a compelling BDSM romance with a unique premise and well-developed characters. While the initial dynamics between the protagonists were a bit off-putting, the story quickly becomes engaging as it delves into their emotional struggles and healing. The Scottish setting and the author‚Äôs signature style make this an enjoyable read.

review: The story centers on a marriage of convenience between Killian Barclay, a grumpy Scottish billionaire who rarely leaves his family manor, and Sylvie, the woman his family manipulates to persuade him to relinquish the estate. The forced proximity and enemies-to-lovers dynamic make for an engaging premise.

Killian and Sylvie are richly developed characters whose journey through a fake marriage and shared living space fosters significant personal growth and emotional connection. Their grumpy x grumpy dynamic is particularly effective, with their witty banter adding to the charm. What begins as a superficial arrangement transforms into a deeply emotional bond, highlighted by moments like Killian's kiss, which symbolizes a profound sense of belonging.
This book exemplifies a classic Sara Cate novel, skillfully combining intense spice with emotional depth. The Scottish twist adds a distinctive flavor, setting it apart within the genre.

The story is emotionally resonant, featuring moments that deeply connect with readers. One standout quote encapsulates this sentiment: ‚ÄúHis kiss feels like crawling back into my own bed after months away. It feels like finding the one other soul on this planet that matches mine. It feels like home.‚Äù
conclusion: This novel is a captivating blend of spice, emotion, and unique storytelling, with a grumpy x grumpy, enemies-to-lovers dynamic that evolves into a deeply emotional and satisfying romance. The Scottish twist and the author's signature style make it a standout read.

review: I adored the marriage of convenience trope, particularly how the characters began with a mutual dislike. Their journey of navigating complicated feelings while healing from personal traumas was both heartwarming and heartbreaking.

The intense chemistry between Sylvie and Killian is a standout feature of the story. Killian, a brooding hero haunted by his past, has isolated himself in his Scottish manor, while Sylvie grapples with her own struggles and seeks to understand her identity. Their sharp banter and slow-burn romance create an electric dynamic. I appreciated witnessing their growth and the evolution of their love, as their journey of healing and self-discovery adds significant emotional depth to the narrative.
*Keep Me* is a captivating read for fans of grumpy heroes, flawed characters, and slow-burn romance. I eagerly anticipate where the story will lead next!
conclusion: *Keep Me* delivers a satisfying mix of spice, emotional depth, and compelling character dynamics. While it may not reach the same level of heat as some other works, it still offers a captivating slow-burn romance with well-developed characters and engaging tropes.

Killian is a damaged, grumpy hero who‚Äôs spent years hiding from the world in his Scottish manor, while Sylvie is struggling with the fallout of her past and trying to figure out who she is. review: I enjoyed the plot, particularly the arranged marriage and the dislike-to-love trope. It was an engaging experience, and who can resist a guy with a Scottish accent and a hint of vulnerability?

The book features strong character development, particularly for the main characters. However, I found the female protagonist somewhat annoying, which detracted from my overall enjoyment, even as her character evolved throughout the story.

This author is an auto-buy and auto-read for me. I adore her writing, stories, and the emotions she evokes with each book. *Keep Me* showcases a different style from her usual work, but I appreciate her willingness to explore something personal and creatively unique. It's a testament to her unapologetic artistry.

While I enjoyed the read, certain sections of the story didn't engage me as much as her previous works. I appreciate the author's attempt to take a different direction, but it ultimately fell short of fully captivating me.
conclusion: *Keep Me* by the author is a new adult contemporary romance with a unique style compared to her usual works. While it features a compelling plot, engaging tropes, and strong character growth, the FMC‚Äôs occasional annoyance and some pacing issues kept it from being a standout read for me. Still, it was a fun, spicy, and heartfelt story.

**Conclusion:**  
*Keep Me* by Sara Cate is a new adult contemporary romance with a unique style compared to her usual works. conclusion: Despite some pacing issues and underdeveloped elements, I still enjoyed this romance and am excited to see what the author comes up with next.

conclusion: Overall, *Keep Me* by the author was an enjoyable read with a compelling premise and strong character dynamics, particularly Sylvie‚Äôs fierceness and her chemistry with Killian. However, the rushed romantic progression, editing errors, and unmet expectations for spice and cultural depth were notable letdowns. Despite these flaws, the book successfully sets the stage for what comes next.

review: The book excels in its portrayal of BDSM, but its toxic relationship dynamics and uneven character development diminish the overall experience. The happy ending feels unearned and fleeting, as only one character confronts their issues, leaving the future of the relationship in doubt.

In this story, the male protagonist, Killian, is portrayed as toxic and manipulative. His derogatory remarks, such as calling the female protagonist a cow, and his deceit regarding their open marriage make him difficult to empathize with. Sylvie, the female protagonist, grapples with the emotional fallout from her parents' neglect and her boyfriend's betrayal. However, her emotional growth feels unrealistic, particularly when her issues seem to resolve abruptly after her parents' secretary is fired. The relationship between Killian and Sylvie is fundamentally flawed, lacking a healthy foundation. Their dynamic is toxic, and the happy ending feels forced and unsustainable. 

On a positive note, Killian's decision to seek therapy and work on himself demonstrates a level of self-awareness and growth that is often absent in similar characters. In contrast, Sylvie's character arc feels incomplete, as she does not experience the same depth of personal development. Her unresolved trauma and absence of therapy leave her growth feeling unfulfilled.

The BDSM elements of the story are skillfully crafted, distinguished by their emotional depth. Unlike many novels that emphasize only the physical aspects, this one beautifully weaves in the emotional connection between the characters. Killian's dominance is portrayed with clear and relatable motivations, a refreshing change from characters whose dominance feels arbitrary or unrealistic. The author approaches the BDSM scenes with taste, ensuring they are both sweet and meaningful rather than merely sensational.
conclusion: This novel is a mixed bag, with well-executed BDSM elements and some positive character growth overshadowed by a toxic relationship and uneven character development. While the emotional depth of the BDSM scenes is commendable, the unresolved issues and unrealistic resolutions make the story feel incomplete and unsatisfying.
reformatted_ori_review:
**Aspects:**  
- **Character Development and Relationships:**  
  - The male protagonist, Killian, is portrayed as toxic and manipulative. His actions, such as calling the female protagonist a "cow" and lying about their open marriage, make him unlikable and hard to root for.  
  - Sylvie, the female protagonist, is deeply affected by her parents' neglect and her boyfriend's betrayal. However, her emotional growth feels unrealistic, especially when her problems seem resolved after her parents' secretary is fired.  
  - The relationship between Killian and Sylvie is problematic and lacks a healthy foundation. Their dynamic is toxic, and their happy ending feels forced and unsustainable.  

- **Themes and Representation of BDSM:**  
  - The BDSM aspect of the story is well-written and stands out for its emotional depth. Unlike many books that focus solely on the physical aspects, this novel integrates the emotional connection between the characters.  
  - Killian's dominance is portrayed with a clear and understandable motivation, which is refreshing compared to characters who are dominant for arbitrary or unrealistic reasons.  
  - The author handles the BDSM scenes tastefully, making them sweet and meaningful rather than purely sensational.  

- **Character Growth and Therapy:**  
  - Killian's decision to seek therapy and work on himself is a positive aspect of the story. It shows a level of self-awareness and growth that is often missing in similar characters.  
  - Sylvie, on the other hand, does not receive the same level of personal development. Her unresolved trauma and lack of therapy make her character arc feel incomplete.  

- **Overall Satisfaction and Ending:**  
  - While the book has its strengths, particularly in its portrayal of BDSM, the toxic relationship and uneven character development detract from the overall enjoyment.  
  - The happy ending feels unearned and temporary, as only one character addresses their issues, leaving the relationship's future uncertain.  

**Conclusion:**  
This novel is a mixed bag, with well-executed BDSM elements and some positive character growth overshadowed by a toxic relationship and uneven character development. While the emotional depth of the BDSM scenes is commendable, the unresolved issues and unrealistic resolutions make the story feel incomplete and unsatisfying.

- No specific rating scores mentioned in the review.

review: This novel masterfully blends elements of a marriage of convenience, enemies-to-lovers, and grumpy x grumpy dynamics, featuring an age gap between the 25-year-old Sylvie and the 37-year-old Killian. The story pleasantly deviates from its synopsis, delving deeper into the journey of two broken characters discovering love. Sylvie, cut off by her neglectful parents, and Killian, a reclusive Scot, enter into a marriage driven by a $10 million offer and Killian‚Äôs family's hidden motives regarding his manor. While the story takes a moment to gain momentum, it ultimately becomes highly engaging and captivating.

Sylvie is a relatable character grappling with parental neglect, a lack of inspiration, and betrayal from her boyfriend and best friend. Killian, a brooding hero with a tragic past marked by PTSD and agoraphobia, showcases compelling growth and vulnerability. The dynamic between Sylvie and Killian is heartwarming, with their grumpy banter and playful name-calling serving as a unique love language.
The author's talent for crafting flawed characters and depicting their healing journeys is a remarkable strength.
The Scottish manor setting, along with the contrast between Sylvie's chaotic life and Killian's isolated existence, enriched the narrative.
The story delves into themes of healing, trauma, and love, showcasing how both characters support one another through their challenges.

The marriage of convenience trope was skillfully executed, with the couple's gradual journey to love feeling genuine. However, the inclusion of light BDSM elements, raunchy parties, and partner swapping seemed unnecessary and did not significantly enhance the story.
conclusion: *Keep Me* by the author is a compelling story, blending tropes like marriage of convenience and enemies-to-lovers with deeply emotional character arcs. While the story took some time to draw me in, the healing journey of Sylvie and Killian, their grumpy yet endearing dynamic, and the exploration of trauma and love made it a memorable read. Though some elements, like the BDSM themes, felt unnecessary, the overall narrative was satisfying and left me excited for what‚Äôs to come.

review: This novel masterfully weaves together a marriage of convenience, a grumpy/grumpy dynamic, an age gap (25f-37m), forced proximity, and a hate-to-love trope. The alternating perspectives of Killian and Sylvie provide a fresh narrative structure. The ending is both brutal and beautiful, earning a well-deserved 5-star rating from the reader.

Sylvie is a strong, feisty protagonist who experiences significant personal growth after being disowned by her parents and betrayed by her boyfriend. In contrast, Killian, a brooding Scotsman, copes with his pain through isolation. Both characters are broken in their own ways: Sylvie becomes bold and independent, while Killian remains guarded. Their chemistry evolves from animosity to explosive passion, culminating in a profound emotional connection. The hate-to-love dynamic is intense, featuring well-crafted scenes that highlight their fiery chemistry. A key romantic development is Killian's gradual ability to earn Sylvie's submission. The third-act breakup is emotionally devastating yet essential for the story's progression.
conclusion: This novel stands out for its unique Scottish setting, alternating perspectives, and intense hate-to-love romance. The characters' growth, explosive chemistry, and emotional depth make it a memorable read. The audiobook narration further elevates the experience, making it a standout performance.

**Conclusion:**  
This novel stands out for its unique Scottish setting, alternating perspectives, and intense hate-to-love romance. The characters' growth, explosive chemistry, and emotional depth make it a memorable read. The audiobook narration further elevates the experience, making it a standout performance.

review: At first, I struggled to connect with either main character; she appeared spoiled and immature, while he seemed rude and abrasive. However, as the story unfolded, I grew to love both of them. Their journey of healing and personal growth was beautifully depicted, and their character arcs were profoundly moving. The author has a remarkable ability to humanize characters, making them relatable and authentic. I found myself in tears multiple times as I came to understand their backgrounds, and I felt a deep sense of hope for their development.

I appreciated the story's pro-therapy perspective, which underscores that love alone isn't always sufficient to heal someone. It emphasizes the importance of self-love and seeking help as prerequisites for truly loving others and accepting their love in return.
This story is deeply heartfelt and profoundly emotional. I highly recommend having tissues on hand, as it moved me to tears several times.
conclusion: This book is a heartfelt and emotional journey of healing, growth, and self-love. The characters, though initially unlikable, become deeply relatable and endearing as their arcs unfold. The pro-therapy message is a refreshing and important addition to the romance genre. Highly recommended for its emotional depth and powerful storytelling.

review: The central conflict centers on Killian's family attempting to seize the manor from him, introducing significant external pressure to the story. Sylive's impulsive behavior and her financial woes‚Äîsquandering her inheritance in just four months instead of the intended eighteen‚Äîadd further complexity to their lives, resulting in a chaotic yet captivating narrative.

The characters Killian Barclay and Sylive Devereaux are complex and compelling. Killian, a grumpy Scottish billionaire, has transformed his family manor into an adult playground and is determined to stay, while Sylive is impulsive and yearns for love that accepts her true self. Their strikingly similar personalities add depth to their dynamic, making me emotionally invested in their struggles and growth throughout the story. The combination of the grumpy x grumpy trope, along with hate-to-love and instant attraction, creates an electrifying relationship. The palpable tension and chemistry between them kept me eagerly turning the pages to see when they would finally surrender to their feelings. A standout quote encapsulates their connection: *His kisses feel like crawling back into my own bed after months away. It feels like finding the one other soul on this planet that matches mine. It feels like home.* This beautifully conveys the intensity of their bond.
conclusion: This novel is a captivating blend of complex characters, sizzling romantic tension, and a well-crafted plot. The grumpy x grumpy dynamic, combined with the hate-to-love trope, made the story irresistible. I was completely drawn into the emotional depth and chemistry between Killian and Sylive, making this a memorable read.

review: The tension and chemistry between Sylvie and Killian are masterfully crafted. Their push-and-pull dynamic and the will-they/won‚Äôt-they suspense in the first half are utterly captivating. When they finally come together, the intensity of their passion is breathtaking. Their stubbornness and the seemingly insurmountable obstacles they face create a deliciously agonizing tension that I both loved and hated. While I may not like Killian, I sympathize with him; everyone in his life claims to know what's best for him, yet no one truly helps‚Äîonly seeks to control him. This resonates with my own feelings of alienation and misunderstanding. Sylvie, though prickly, is entirely believable and sympathetic due to her circumstances. It‚Äôs hard not to feel compassion for her. Killian, an agoraphobic and broken man grappling with the tragic loss of his parents through drinking and partying, is deeply flawed yet compelling, making him a fascinating character to follow.

The author's writing is impeccable, featuring well-developed character arcs and emotional depth, all while maintaining a perfect balance of kink, tension, and climax. The pacing is captivating, ensuring that every moment of the book is a joy to experience.

This book is a deeply emotional journey, filled with gut-wrenching moments that make you want to both confront and comfort the characters. At its core, it explores the theme of learning to love oneself while grappling with personal brokenness. Sylvie and Killian's fractured pieces fit together in a way that makes their relationship beautifully painful. The intensity of their fear, longing, jealousy, passion, and grief is amplified by the impossible circumstances they face, particularly for Sylvie, who knows their connection will ultimately lead to heartache.
conclusion: Keep Me is an intensely emotional and beautifully written novel that explores the themes of love, self-worth, and healing through the lens of two profoundly broken characters. Sylvie and Killian‚Äôs journey is filled with tension, passion, and heart-wrenching moments that make their relationship both agonizing and perfect. The author has outdone themselves with this book, creating a story that is deeply moving and unforgettable. The audiobook performance further enhances the experience, making it a must-read (and must-listen) for fans of emotional, character-driven romance.

   - The tension, animosity, and chemistry between Sylvie and Killian are exquisite. Their push-and-pull dynamic and the will-they/won‚Äôt-they tension in the first half are captivating.
   - The intensity of their passion once they finally collide is magnifique. Their stubbornness and the seemingly impossible situation they‚Äôre in create agonizing angst and tension that I both hated and loved.

   - Sara Cate‚Äôs writing is immaculate, with well-crafted character arcs, emotional depth, and a perfect balance of kink, tension, and climax.
   - The pacing keeps you hooked from the beginning, with every moment of the book being something I was living for.

- **Audiobook Performance:**
   - The audiobook is phenomenal, with Kelli Tager and Will Watt delivering brilliant performances. It added an extra layer of enjoyment to my reread.

**Conclusion:**
Keep Me is an intensely emotional and beautifully written novel that explores the themes of love, self-worth, and healing through the lens of two profoundly broken characters. Sylvie and Killian‚Äôs journey is filled with tension, passion, and heart-wrenching moments that make their relationship both agonizing and perfect. Sara Cate has outdone herself with this book, creating a story that is deeply moving and unforgettable. The audiobook performance further enhances the experience, making it a must-read (and must-listen) for fans of emotional, character-driven romance.

11/10 recommend.

review: The book is structured into five parts, each told from a different character's perspective. While this approach doesn't detract from the story, I personally prefer alternating chapter viewpoints.

Sylvie and Killian's relationship is both unconventional and captivating. Sylvie, raised in New York by famous parents with sky-high expectations, contrasts sharply with Killian, a reclusive Scot haunted by past trauma. Their charming meet-cute and witty banter enrich their connection, while the nicknames they choose for each other highlight their character growth throughout the story. Their chemistry is palpable, blending angst and desire, though it feels somewhat subdued compared to the author's previous works. I found myself wanting more backstory on Killian's aunt; her character felt underdeveloped, and her actions seemed insufficiently justified by Killian's trauma.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book and highly recommend it, particularly for readers new to this author or those hesitant about exploring kink. The kink elements are more subdued than in her previous works, yet the story still captures the signature Sara Cate essence.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a captivating novel with well-developed characters and a compelling relationship dynamic. While the narrative structure and some supporting characters could have been stronger, the book is an excellent introduction to the author's writing, particularly for those who prefer a tamer approach to kink.

review: The plot is among the author's finest, centering on two broken characters who discover the love and respect they deserve. The revelation of the truth is heart-wrenching, yet it paves the way for a beautiful resolution and an ideal ending for the characters.

Sylvie is the character I connected with most in this story. Her heartbreaking interactions with her parents and her struggle to find her identity resonated deeply with me. I admired her daring, impulsive nature and the courage she displays in facing life's challenges. Killian, on the other hand, is a grumpy, broken-hearted man who isolates himself after his parents' death. Beneath his tough exterior, he is protective and understanding, showing Sylvie just how much she means to him. 

Both characters have poignant backstories that unfold gradually, with Killian's decision to leave his past behind handled particularly well. Their first meeting is a bizarre, disastrous, and humorous encounter that sets the stage for their chemistry and playful banter throughout the book. What begins as a marriage of convenience evolves beautifully as these two broken souls learn to trust and love one another. 

Sylvie harbors a secret that introduces tension and doubt, but I appreciated her proactive approach to changing her circumstances, even when the outcome is unexpected. I loved all the characters in this book, and I believe it has the potential to become one of my favorites.

The author has quickly become one of my favorites, and I anticipate enjoying everything they write. *Keep Me* stands out from their previous works, not only because it diverges from the *Salacious Players* universe but also due to its unique structure, which I thoroughly enjoyed.

review: The story centers on an arranged marriage between Sylvie and Killian, initiated by Killian‚Äôs sister. Sylvie agrees to marry him for one year in exchange for ten million dollars, a tempting offer she can't refuse. The narrative delves into themes of trauma, healing, and the transformative power of love. Initially resistant to romance, both characters ultimately find solace and strength in one another. The slow-burn romance features an enemies-to-lovers dynamic, reminiscent of *Beauty and the Beast*, with Killian as the brooding, isolated man and Sylvie as the independent woman who disrupts his life.

Killian is one of the grumpiest characters I've encountered in a while, but Sylvie matches his energy with her fiery personality. Their crass, wicked, and sexually charged banter is among the best I've read. Both characters are deeply flawed, using anger as a defense mechanism shaped by their traumatic pasts and lack of love. They are broken individuals who find healing and love in each other. Circumstances force Sylvie and Killian into an arranged marriage, which serves as a catalyst for their emotional growth. Starting as enemies, they gradually uncover an unexpected connection. While the book features a moderate level of spice, the emphasis is on their emotional bond rather than explicit scenes. Once they surrender to their attraction, their relationship becomes intense and passionate, showcasing their protective and possessive natures as they stand up for each other at any cost.

This story is profoundly emotional, capturing moments of frustration, passion, and heartwarming connection. Sylvie and Killian's transformation from hatred to love is both raw and beautiful. Their protective and supportive dynamic is truly touching, as they uplift and believe in each other, ultimately discovering a love they never thought possible.
conclusion: *Keep Me* is a beautifully crafted story of two broken individuals who find healing and love in each other. The slow-burn romance, enemies-to-lovers dynamic, and emotional depth make it a compelling read. The audiobook narration is outstanding, bringing the characters and their journey to life. While the spice level is moderate, the focus on emotional connection and character development makes this a standout novel.
